body: @swami-veeramani if there are no other changes I can go ahead and merge the code.

LGTM.
So in each run, if any workunit fails, nothing will be persisted, this run will appear to have never been happened. This definitely works, but in this case is it possible to persist the data and actualHighWm of the successful workunits, while for the failed workunits, don't persist the data but persist their lowWm? This way those successful workunits won't be wasted and the next run can still start at the correct Wm for each workunit.

It all depends on which `JobCommitPolicy` is used. If `JobCommitPolicy.COMMIT_ON_FULL_SUCCESS` is used, the job state of a failed job won't be persisted since commit will not happen. For a successful job, the job state will be persisted if the commit is successful. If `JobCommitPolicy.COMMIT_ON_PARTIAL_SUCCESS` is used, however, the job state will be persisted if commit is successful. 

Since commit is not atomic, it is possible that commit fails in the middle and data is partially committed. In this case, the job state is not persisted, and this may lead to duplicate data in the next run. 

Persisting job state regardlessly may lead to missing data if data commit fails but high watermark is updated and persisted. Having duplicated data is better than missing data IMO.
Updated c1e8d1b to move `persistJobState` to after `commitJob` to make it clear that job state persistence happens only if job commit is successful.
Updated, since `switch(string)` not supported in Java 6. Changed to if-else.

@ibuenros can you review this? I just realized that `JobMetrics.stopMetricReporting` should be called somewhere soon after you merged in #156. Then I realized `setup` and `cleanup` are better places to start and stop metric reporting respectively. Also the `Configuration` object returned by `context.getConfiguration()` has all job configuration properties in it. So now the method `JobMetrics.startMetricReporting(Configuration)` gets used.
@liyinan926 It looks good, but I would want to test that the expected properties actually get propagated to the mappers. It will take me some time to do that.
Sure. Let me know once you are done with the testing.

@zliu41 @ydailinkedin @chavdar can you take a look? Updated with the following changes:
1. `persistJobState` is called in a finally clause after `commitJob` so it's always called. 
2. `persistJobState` checks the state of each task and restore the previous actual high watermark for a task if the task has not been successfully committed.
3. `Task` now backs up the previous actual high watermark before starting the extraction.
4. `WorkUnitState.getActualHighWatermark` now checks the existence of `workunit.state.actual.high.water.mark` and returns `null` if the property is not set. `KafkaSource` is updated accordingly to skip previous `WorkUnitState`s that do not have that property set.
5. `KafkaExtractor` is updated to not commit actual high watermark if the task fails.
@narasimhareddyv please also take a look. Thanks!
@chavdar just a remainder please take a look at this PR when you get a chance. Thanks!
Updated cace7f4 to fix the dependencies.
@zliu41 @liyinan926 rebased it all into one commit. This PR is good from my end. Let me know if you guys have any last minute comments.
@sahilTakiar can you take a look at this?
@zliu41 this PR has been failing build on both Java 7 & 8: https://travis-ci.org/linkedin/gobblin/builds/66302548.
@liyinan926 addressed comments except for the one in State.java (still waiting for a reply).

LGTM although not sure why the build failed.

In a future PR it may be nice to have a script that checks if every .java file has a properly formed license file, perhaps we can even make the script part of the build.
The build failed on Java 8 on one of the tests, but I am not sure why the test failed either. We can add such a script to the Travis-CI build.
@liyinan926 addressed new comments. @zliu41 do you have some time to look at the PR? it's fairly short.
@chavdar have you got a chance to look at this PR? Thanks!
Minor comment, can you also do a git pull and merge. There were some updates to gobblin-test-harness to fix a bunch of the license headers.

Answering your questions above: 
1. It's possible that a `MultiWorkUnit` further contains `MultiWorkUnit`s and this may go really deep, so flattening should be recursive.
2. It is not changing the way tasks are created and handled. Each `WorkUnit` (flattened) is still corresponding to one task. However, the original list of `WorkUnit`s (unflattened) are still persisted in their original form in the MR mode.

So the semantics of handling `WorkUnit`s stays the same.
@zliu41 addressed comments. The issue around the comma separated list might still be up for debate.
@chavdar updated. Replaced `PasswordUtils` with `PasswordManager`, which caches instances, and supports both encrypted and plain password.
We also need a simple command line tool that can encrypt/decrypt a password given a master password.
Why are we removing `compaction.force.reprocess`? It seems to me it is a reasonable use case that users want to re-compact the input every run, even if the output was already compacted.

@chavdar updated. Added command line tool `CLIPasswordEncryptor`. After building gobblin there will be a `gobblin-utility.tar.gz` file in `build/gobblin-utility/distributions`. Unzip it and there will be a runnable jar.
One should only re-compact if there's a newer file (outlier) in the input folder. Otherwise, always re-compacting is a waste. I'll add the outlier handling logic later in a separate PR.
@ibuenros updated. Added property "compaction.overwrite.output.dir", default false. If inputdir = outputdir, this must be set to true.

Can you fix tests before merging.
Also, just remembered, if the jobmanager / resourcemanager is localhost, we should resolve localhost.

Looks like the build is failing because the class https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/blob/master/gobblin-azkaban/src/main/java/gobblin/azkaban/AzkabanIntegrationTestLauncher.java is throwing some build errors related to the API changes. Can you resolve the errors.

Other than that, the changes LGTM.

@pcadabam @sahilTakiar @liyinan926 can at least two of you review?
This is a giant change. A lot of refactoring, and some new logic. I will setup a meeting to walk through the PR (probably easier that way).
@chavdar updated. Changed key of instance cache from `Optional<String>` to `Map.Entry<Optional<String>, Boolean>`, where true means strong encryptor and false means basic encryptor.
